Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov

Class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kraskov.MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2
    public abstract class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov
extends MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
implements MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

    Computes the differential mutual information of two given multivariate sets of observations (implementing MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate), using Kraskov-Stoegbauer-Grassberger (KSG) estimation (see Kraskov et al., below). The implementation is made using fast-neighbour searches with an underlying k-d tree algorithm. This is an abstract class to gather common functionality between the two algorithms defined by Kraskov et al. Two child classes MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1 and MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2 then actually implement the two algorithms in the Kraskov et al. paper

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • For constructors see the child classes.
    • Further properties are defined in setProperty(String, String).
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!

    References:

    • Kraskov, A., Stoegbauer, H., Grassberger, P., "Estimating mutual information", Physical Review E 69, (2004) 066138.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www), Ipek Ã–zdemir

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the KSG MI calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_K -- number of k nearest neighbours to use in joint kernel space in the KSG algorithm (default is 4).
        • PROP_NORM_TYPE -- normalization type to apply to working out the norms between the points in each marginal space. Options are defined by KdTree.setNormType(String) - default is EuclideanUtils.NORM_MAX_NORM.
        • PROP_DYN_CORR_EXCL_TIME -- a dynamics exclusion time window, also known as Theiler window (see Kantz and Schreiber); default is 0 which means no dynamic exclusion window.
        • PROP_NUM_THREADS -- the integer number of parallel threads to use in the computation. Can be passed as a string "USE_ALL" to use all available processors on the machine. Default is "USE_ALL".
        • any valid properties for MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setProperty(String, String).

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from class: MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.

        This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.sourceObservations and MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.destObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.

        Specified by:

        Overrides:

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Allow child classes to throw an exception if there is an issue detected specific to that calculator.

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the average value of the measure from the previously-supplied samples.

        Returns:
        the average MI in nats (not bits!)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations​(int[] reordering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception

        Compute the mutual information if the first (source) variable were ordered as per the ordering specified in newOrdering.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of a shuffled source series here.

        This method is primarily intended for use in MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int[][]) however has been made public in case users wish to access it.

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Child implementations must only over-write lastAverage if newOrdering is null, which indicates that the original ordering should be used (making this equivalent to a call to InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.computeAverageLocalOfObservations()).

        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        reordering - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create a surrogate source time series. It is an array of length N (where would be the value returned by MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the MI under the new ordering, in nats (not bits!).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the MI, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local MIs in nats
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations​(double[][] states1,
                                                      double[][] states2)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        states1 - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number)
        states2 - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeFromObservations

        protected double[] computeFromObservations​(boolean returnLocals,
                                           double[][][] newObservations)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        This protected method handles the multiple threads which computes either the average or local MI (over parts of the total observations), computing the x and y distances between all tuples in time.

        The method returns:

        1. for (returnLocals == false), an array of size 1, containing the average MI
        2. for local MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local MI values
        Parameters:
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        newObservations - set to null for computing for the observation set for the PDF, or pass in a new set of observations to compute the average/locals for (using the existing observations to construct the PDF)
        Returns:
        either the average MI, or array of local MI value, in nats not bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageConditionalEntropy

        public double computeAverageConditionalEntropy()
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Use the same nearest neighbour searches to return a KL-based conditional entropy, sharing the neighbour search radius. With reference to the KSG paper, this takes the KL-based estimator for H(X) (eqn 22) and adds it to the negative of MI. It should also be noted that if the variables are normalised, this changes the absolute values of the entropies, and they become relative to normalised variables. Since this is a side-method for this estimator, it is currently is only implemented single threaded on CPU. It should also be considered experimental - this will eventually be moved to its own estimator.
        Returns:
        the average conditional entropy of variable1 given variable2 in nats (not bits!)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • partialComputeFromObservations

        protected abstract double[] partialComputeFromObservations​(int startTimePoint,
                                                           int numTimePoints,
                                                           boolean returnLocals)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of each Kraskov algorithm, computing the number of nearest neighbours in each dimension for a sub-set of the data points. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data.

        The method returns:

        1. for average MIs (returnLocals == false), the relevant sums of digamma(n_x+1) and digamma(n_y+1) for a partial set of the observations
        2. for local MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local MI values
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        an array of sum of digamma(n_x+1) and digamma(n_y+1), then sum of n_x and finally sum of n_y (these latter two are for debugging purposes).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • partialComputeFromNewObservations

        protected abstract double[] partialComputeFromNewObservations​(int startTimePoint,
                                                              int numTimePoints,
                                                              double[][] newVar1Observations,
                                                              double[][] newVar2Observations,
                                                              boolean returnLocals)
                                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of each Kraskov algorithm, computing the number of nearest neighbours in each dimension for a sub-set of the data points. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data. In particular, this method differs from partialComputeFromObservations(int, int, boolean) because it operates on a new set of observations (using the old set of observations for constructing the search spaces and PDFs)

        The method returns:

        1. for average MIs (returnLocals == false), the relevant sums of digamma(n_x+1), digamma(n_y+1) for a partial set of the observations
        2. for local MIs (returnLocals == true), the array of local MI values
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        newVar1Observations - new time series of observations for variable 1
        newVar2Observations - new time series of observations for variable 2
        returnLocals - whether to return an array or local values, or else sums of these values
        Returns:
        an array of sum of digamma(n_x+1) and digamma(n_y+1), then sum of n_x and finally sum of n_y (these latter two are for debugging purposes).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • gpuComputeFromObservations

        protected double[] gpuComputeFromObservations​(int startTimePoint,
                                              int numTimePoints,
                                              boolean returnLocals,
                                              int nb_surrogates,
                                              int[][] newOrderings)
                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for GPU implementations. This method serves the same purpose as partialComputeFromObservations, but for GPU computation. Each algorithm must override this method and implement a GPU routine to calculate all values in a single call to the GPU code.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate MI calculations.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Overrides:
        computeSignificance in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples for permutations to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance​(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a resampled distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement a clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        We permute the source variable against the destination to be consistent with the description in EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int[][]) (though in theory this doesn't matter for this function call).

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Overrides:
        computeSignificance in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computePredictionErrorsFromObservations

        public double[] computePredictionErrorsFromObservations​(boolean predictFirstVariable)
                                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the prediction error in one variable from the k nearest neighbours (kNNs) of the observation of the other variable. The kNNs of the variable to predict from are formed from the supplied norm type within that variable. The number of kNNs to use here is the current property value set for PROP_K. The prediction error is a sum of absolute errors for each dimension within the variable to predict
        Parameters:
        predictFirstVariable - true for predicting the first variable (Source) or false for predicting the second variable (destination)
        Returns:
        array of prediction errors for each dimension of the predicted variable
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computePredictionErrorsFromObservations

        public double[] computePredictionErrorsFromObservations​(boolean predictFirstVariable,
                                                        int kNNs)
                                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the prediction error in one variable from the k nearest neighbours (kNNs) of the observation of the other variable. The kNNs of the variable to predict from are formed from the supplied norm type within that variable. The prediction error is a sum of absolute errors for each dimension within the variable to predict
        Parameters:
        predictFirstVariable - true for predicting the first variable (Source) or false for predicting the second variable (destination)
        kNNs - number of nearest neighbours to use
        Returns:
        array of prediction errors for each dimension of the predicted variable
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • partialComputePredictionErrorFromObservations

        protected double[] partialComputePredictionErrorFromObservations​(int startTimePoint,
                                                                 int numTimePoints,
                                                                 int kNNs,
                                                                 boolean predictFirstVariable)
                                                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected method to be used internally for threaded implementations. This method implements the guts of examining prediction errors in one variable from the k nearest neighbours of the other. It is intended to be called by one thread to work on that specific sub-set of the data.
        Parameters:
        startTimePoint - start time for the partial set we examine
        numTimePoints - number of time points (including startTimePoint to examine)
        kNNs - number of nearest neighbours to use
        predictFirstVariable - whether to use the second variable to predict the first (true) or first variable to predict the second (false)
        Returns:
        an array of the sum of square prediction errors for each dimension within the predicted variable.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
